title: YouTube CEO Susan Wojcicki Apologizes Over Verification Changes
text:
YouTube’s chief executive apologized to the creator community Friday over a row sparked by the company’s decision to remove the verification status of its content creators.

“I’m sorry for the frustration & hurt that we caused with our new approach to verification,” CEO Susan Wojcicki said in a tweet Friday. “While trying to make improvements, we missed the mark.” She added that YouTube will work on addressing users’ concerns and will provide more updates soon.

The concession came a day after the company, a unit of Google and Alphabet Inc. , announced changes to its verification system, involving new eligibility requirements designed to verify channels it identifies as prominent and clearly needing proof of authenticity.

YouTube has been a sore spot for Google this year. Staffers companywide objected this summer to the video platform’s treatment of hate speech. Some LGBTQ employees, in particular, said Google no longer deserved to participate in commemorative Pride activities. Ms. Wojcicki apologized for her handling of those complaints, too.

Google Chief Executive Sundar Pichai has become involved in righting the ship, The Wall Street Journal earlier reported.

YouTube said this week that its new verified channels would now come with a look that “helps distinguish the official channel of the creator, celebrity or brand it represents.” The new look would be displayed more consistently across channel pages, search and comments, according to the company.

In conjunction with the news, announced in a blog post, some popular YouTube creators had received emails informing them about the loss of their verified status Thursday. The company said Friday that no one has lost a verification badge yet. The message should be treated as an advance notice that can be appealed, the company said.

Twitter Inc., Facebook Inc. and Instagram have all made changes to their verification policies, which are designed to make it easier for the public to find the official accounts of their favorite celebrity, organization or brand.

The moves come as the video-streaming platform grapples with how to manage users on its platform. YouTube, which Google acquired in 2006, is the world’s largest video-streaming platform. The company has said its users watch more than one billion hours of content each day. Over the past couple of years, the site has been criticized for the way its powerful recommendation engine can steer users to violent content or conspiracy theories, as well as how the platform protects its large numbers of young viewers.

In August, Google pulled 210 YouTube channels from its platform, citing evidence that the content appeared to be part of a coordinated disinformation campaign by the Chinese government in response to pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong.

The company has also said it would change its policies on how it protects children using its platform. Google recently agreed to pay a $170 million fine to settle a yearlong federal investigation into how YouTube collects data on children and sells ads for such products as Barbie dolls and Play-Doh. YouTube said it would provide new protections for children on its video platform.

—Rob Copeland contributed to this article.

Write to Kimberly Chin at kimberly.chin@wsj.com
description: YouTube’s Chief Executive Susan Wojcicki has apologized for concerns over the decision to remove the verification status of its content creators.
